subject: YAPC::EU CFP; TPF grant proposals; New book about one-liners
header: Wow, I don't know what happened, but this week we got so many posts. I had a really hard time to keep this newsletter at a reasonable size.
I saved some of the posts for later, in case next week, when the weather improves, the authors will go out instead of publishing articles.

entries.title: YAPC::EU::2012 Call for Speakers
entries.text: YAPC::Europe will take place between 20-22 August, in Frankfurt. You are invited to submit talks already.

entries.title: Perl Data Language (PDL) 2.4.10 Release
entries.text: .... This reminds me if we could marry Padre with PDL, that could be an interesting step towards providing an alternative to Matlab.

entries.title: Brocade Execs Offer Look Under OpenScript Engine's Hood
entries.text: I especially liked the part: 'Basically, we ported the Perl programming language to the ADX application processor so that you can use APIs to control application delivery with a script. This means you get all the Perl goodness that you know and love for writing custom scripts to read or write layer three to seven headers based on your particular application needs.'

entries.title: 2012Q1 Grant Proposals
entries.text: Alberto Sim√µes announced 3 grant proposals that were submitted to TPF. Please check them and comment on them.

entries.title: Announcing the third e-book of Peteris Krumins 'Perl One-Liners Explained'
entries.text: It contains 111 pages and explains 130 unique one-liners and I already bought it.

entries.title: A Perl lexer and parser for Graphviz dot files
entries.text: Ron Savage announced GraphViz2::Marpa and linked to a long article he wrote about 'Lexing and Parsing with Marpa'.

entries.title: The 'Perl Tutorial' Tutorial
entries.text: Joel Berger provides some directions how to select a good Perl tutorial. (one could, of course, just check out mine :-)

entries.title: A Real Developer Challenge
entries.text: Michael G Schwern describes how he thinks developers should be interview by potential employers. I am not sure if he talks from experience as an interviewer or as someone who is applying for a job. In either case interesting point.

entries.title: HTML::ParseBrowser rides again
entries.text: Neil Bowers describes the process of taking over maintenances of a CPAN module.

entries.title: Why I Run Tests on Install
entries.text: In response to an article by Jonathan Swartz arguing against running tests on installation, chromatic describes why he runs test and why he was looking for ways to improve the speed of testing. Being able to run the tests after installation would be nice and would be able to help in case we upgrade a dependency that breaks an already installed module.

entries.title: Module releases and Test reports (A history of releases and perls)
entries.text: Joseph Walton, author of XML::Writers takes the data from CPAN testers and shows some interesting graphs about the relation ship between the release dates of perl, XML::Writer and the respective test reports on CPAN Testers.

entries.title: True + True == 2
entries.text: 'don't assume the author is an idiot'. An obvious refactoring and an educational post goes wrong. There is a certain relaxing feeling that even people like Schwern can make mistakes. Sometimes.

entries.title: udp_server with IO::Lambda
entries.text: Dmitry Karasik shows and explains how to write a udp_server using his IO::Lambda module.

entries.title: Perforce auth-check trigger for Unix passwd file
entries.text: Small but useful script for Perforce users.

entries.title: Barack Obama's coming to the DC-Baltimore Perl Workshop?
entries.text: Tim Heaney (oylenshpeegul) uses Google::Directions to find out how could the president of USA visit the workshop. I am quite sure he will have to pick an alternate route, now that the planned one was exposed to dangerous Perl Hackers.

entries.title: Perl: When DWIM Doesn't
entries.text: An article by Douglas from Shutterstock about two surprising features of Perl that can easily trip programmers. Some interesting comments included.

entries.title: t1: Expressing integers using four nines
entries.text: Moritz Lenz writes about the first task in the Perl 6 coding contest that ended recently.

entries.title: Debugging Perl scripts
entries.text: This is one of the first entries of the Perl Tutorial that gives some simple ideas how to debug Perl code.

entries.title: Perl on the command line
entries.text: While in most of the Perl tutorial I deal with scripts, here I give a small glimpse into the world of one-liners.

entries.title: The right way to install CPAN modules
entries.text: perlbrew? CPAN.pm ? cpanm? apt-get?

entries.title: Perl Workshop in Israel
entries.text: February 28, 2012, Ramat Gan, Israel

entries.title: German Perl workshop
entries.text: March 5-7, 2012, Erlangen, Germany

entries.title: DC-Baltimore Perl workshop
entries.text: April 14, 2012, Catonsville, MD, USA

entries.title: YAPC::NA
entries.text: June 13-15, 2012, Madison, Wisconsin, USA
